WRITING.TITLE: b'Perfume Roadblock'
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Hi all! Love this community. I feel like I've hit a block in discovering new fragrances that I really like. I just bought a bunch of travel bottles from Sephora to try (blind buys are sometimes foolish, I know, but I also know what notes and combinations I tend to like). I'm hoping I can glean some insight from you all. I love white floral, woodsy/spicy, rich vanilla, and pear. I also like unique/unisex fragrances. Also interested to know if My Way is worth the hype?   Perfumes I love: Dior Hypnotic Poison,  Chloe Nomade,  Mugler Angel/Aura,  YSL Libre Intense,  Givenchy Hot Couture,  Nest Sunkissed Hibiscus,  Replica Whispers in the Library.   I was very disappointed in: V and R Flowerbomb Ruby Orchid,  Valentino Born in Roma,  Miss Dior EDP.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: It\'s a hard narrative to write, I think. The lived experiences of mixed-race people are often subjugated, separated, outcasted and unrelatable.  Try not to focus SO much on their race; it\'s often not the colour of the skin overtly that causes mixed-race people to be rejected. Negative connotations of mixed-ness, being a "mutt" and dirty are usually why people reject mixed people.  Your character may find solace in family and the not-closed-minded community.  The idea of "otherness" is definitely going to be a big feature of your narrative, I anticipate. An easy way to think of it is as being bullied for having bad teeth or bad skin. These are things that you can\'t control, through no fault of your own. What makes being mixed-race more distinctly painful from these other kinds of discrimination is that it is so fundamental to your identity.  I am white-passing but I identify as both black and white. People have said things like "you don\'t look black", "you don\'t act black", "you\'re white and you know it". I have never felt "accepted" by either group and actually hung out with other mixed-raced kids mostly.  For resources, check out things like "Mixed Remixed", search "multiracial resources" and "biracial resources". Also, do some research about mixed-race celebrities; there\'s more than you might think! I\'d be happy to offer any anecdotal insight, too.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: The shitty food, getting off the bus a minute before the top of the hour and hustling to MN or IB, getting a Starbucks and hiding in the library for hours. The agony is nice.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I'm a student in university and I can't be high during class, whether it's cannabis or opiates.   Certain cannabis strains are particularly not-high-making, even with amounts of THC. I've found that CBD doesn't work for my pain but definitely improves my mood. I would maybe try a balanced cannabis or cannabis oil with equal parts CBD to THC and see how that works for you.

WRITING.TITLE: b"How to exercise when you're always exhausted?"
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Howdy,  I love this group. Each time I post I always feel heard and related to.   I've been diagnosed with fibromyalgia. My joints ache and I'm always fatigued and tired and I have a constant headache.   I used to exercise regularly, using barbells and free weights mostly. I can barely stand to stand up for very long some days.   Particularly, I don't want to gain weight. I've made dietary changes that I'm sure will contribute to maintaining a healthy weight but exercise really does well for my mental and physical health.   How can I start slowly to try to get back into an exercise routine? I'm sore but I really need to exercise.

WRITING.TITLE: b'Fresh Fibromyalgia Diagnosis: Treatment Options?'
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Hey y'all,  I just recieved a diagnosis from my rheumatologist today: fibromyalgia.   He recommended to me CBD and I've got a prescription. He also recommended switching off from naproxen (which helps tales off about 50% the pain) to Cymbalta. I understand that it's main use is for fibromyalgia, but I'm pretty averse to going on antidepressants just because my family hasn't had positive experiences with them and I don't feel depressed or anxious at all. I'm just exhausted and have a hard time sleeping because of the pain.   I'm in Canada, 21F and normally healthy. All my tests and labs came back normal. I'm seeing a neurologist at the end of the month.   I'm considering acupuncture as a possible avenue of treatment as well. I understand this disease is ridiculously a mystery, so I'm curious if anyone has any recommendations or even just experiences for treatment option.

WRITING.TITLE: b'Chronic joint pain and headaches'
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I am a normally healthy 21-year-old female, fit and no pre-existing conditions. Two months ago, I woke up with an achy body and headache. The joints in my knees, wrists, elbows and ankles feel tingly and burny deep in the joint, though there is no visible swelling, redness or heat. They are tender to the touch, though I'm not fatigued. I've had knee surgery, sports injuries, and a sore body from the gym, but I've never felt anything quite like this.   My headache starts as a dull ache and escalates to intense stabbing pains. I have been tested for lupus, RA, cancer, infection COVID19 (all negative,) had a non-contrast CT scan of my head (negative), and have been taking naproxen as a result, though I still am getting breakthrough pain. It has never helped the headache but the joint pain has been reduced. Both ice and heat help the pain. I have trouble sleeping and activity seems to make it worse. I've been referred to both a rheumatologist and neurologist by my family doctor, and she is really quite stumped.   Has anyone else ever experienced any similar symptoms? How do you advocate for yourself and your health (particularly as a young person) with seemingly no data that shows your pain?

You\'re definitely mixed-race; though if you choose to identify as either race, that\'s completely up to you. I\'m a very white-passing person though I would consider myself to be "mixed".

WRITING.TITLE: b'Severe joint pain and headache for two weeks, non-stop (20F)'
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: For two weeks I (20F), (5\'4, 140LBS, white/black, fit athlete) have been suffering from severe joint pain and a persistent headache. I wake up in the morning very stiff, and the joint pain worsens over the course of the day. The pain is in my wrists, ankles, elbows and knees and sometimes in my fingers. The aching and stiffness will increase, and then the pain will flare-up. The pain in the joint feels tingly and burning, and it doesn\'t feel superficial. It radiates through the joint. It feels like I\'ve sat too close to a fire inside my joints. Moving does not help the pain. I can still do daily tasks but slower and I am usually exhausted by the end of it.  After an allergic reaction to azithromycin, I got serum sickness when I was 14. The dull ache and persistent pain is the best way to compare the pain. It does not feel like an injury, exercise soreness or flu-like.  In addition to the joint pain, I\'ve had a headache, It appears to act similarly to the joint pain. I wake up with it, and at first, it feels like a caffeine withdrawal headache. However, caffeine doesn\'t change it. The headache is persistent and achy and it escalates to a stabbing sensation, in bouts of usually 3-5 "stabs". I have had this headache for 12 days now.  There is no visible swelling or redness in or around the joints.  I\'ve considered a food sensitivity and kept a log of my pain, what I\'ve eaten and the drugs I took. I can\'t seem to find any patterns.  I\'ve been taking 2 Aleve in the morning and 1 at night, Tylenol intermittently and topical treatments such as Voltaren and Tiger Balm. Both ice and heat help the pain. I\'ve also been taking turmeric pills for potential inflammation. My mind feels clear, and I feel completely healthy otherwise. I am usually healthy. The pain has ranged from a 3/10 to a 7/10. I have woken up in the night in pain from my joints aching. Nothing has sufficiently helped the pain.  My doctor ordered blood tests and they were negative for infection, cancer markers, RA and lupus markers. My MCH is low (but close to normal range) and my RDW is high (and also close to normal range). However, my ferritin, B12 and hemoglobin levels are all within the normal range.  I drink occasionally, I don\'t smoke and I use cannabis occasionally.  I really appreciate your help, I\'m perplexed.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Many schools have data organizing LSAT takers by major, and amongst them criminology/criminal justice students (on average) tend to rank quite low on the ballot. Engineering, mathematics, philosophy, political science, economics and other STEM majors tend to excel on the LSAT, likely because of the logical reasoning and analytical reasoning sections. It's not to say that being a crim major puts you at a disadvantage on the LSAT, but for some reason, they statically don't do as well as other majors. It seems to be the case that certain majors are better prepared by their degrees to do well on the LSAT compared to others. Not trying to discourage at all!! The LSAT is a learnable and teachable test that anyone can excel in if they practice enough.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Political science as a major I think is very underrated in terms of difficulty. While it's not hard to do well if you're politically minded, if you're only taking it to get into law school or something, you'll probably struggle. It's very writing and reading intensive, with a mix of theory and normative premises. For political science, it's not enough to just read but you have to make connections and explain connections. A lot of explanation. I'm third-year and most of my polisci courses were easy, but there are a few that I found to be more difficult than others.    I figure history is probably the same. Consider your aptitude! If you're interested in history and can understand and make connections about what you're reading, you should be fine.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I'm sorry this happened to you. While UTM campus is private property, it'd be a very hard case to prove negligence on. It's good that you told campus police. I'd recommend keeping a notebook or some way to keep track of the events surrounding your slip. This includes the slip itself, the location, temperature and time of the slip, the police report, and the dentist visits. If there are follow up visits or if you need more medical attention that arose because of your slip, I'd include that too. Did you get pictures of the location of your slip? If not, I'd do that ASAP.   Postal workers slip on the job and they sue. With a private institution like UTM, with a high volume of people, there is a high expectation that ice and snow will be cleared within a reasonable amount of time. To do otherwise I'd consider negligence.   If you want to try to sue, other people mentioned some free consultation personal injury lawyers. It's worth a shot. Good luck!

Like someone else said in another comment, some universities allow you to explain the reason for discrepancies on your transcript or your GPA.   If you make sure the rest of your application is solid, I figure you should be ok!   If you really want in depth exam of your chances at X, Y, Z university, join a Grad school chances subreddit like r/ChanceMe and r/gradadmissions.  Be sure to be specific when you post there, they're pretty big subs and a lot of people will be able to give you a decent assessment of your chance there. Good luck!

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: You can message me. Depending on the content I might be able to give you some reading, writing, notetaking and study tips. Otherwise, some courses offer FSG (facilitated study groups) which may be useful. Like other other people said, you should check out the RGASC in MN. Also, I might suggest talking to an academic advisor. They're really nice at the registrar and will help you. Reaching out to your profs and TAs IS scary but I think it'll give you some real insight.   I'm assuming you're in first year. Remember that it's ok to change paths. If the courses you're taking are not something that you care about, you're definitely going to find it more difficult to engage with the material.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Lippincott for any political science, if you're good at listening and taking notes. Really cool guy.  Clark in philosophy. Sepielli in philosophy.   Some professors I just can't... A lot of recommendations for Pond. 214 was an easy-A but his sense of humour is kinda wild.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: 10/10 would not recommend copy and pasting anything, any time. It's a lazy thing and paraphrasing will help you understand more in the long-run and you'll sound like you know what you're talking about. I'm in the humanities/social sciences and I've never submitted a paper over 10% similarity. Talk to your TA and prof ASAP. If you're struggling with writing or paraphrasing or citing your sources, go to the RGASC. It's in MN. The librarians are also really helpful with citations.

WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I claim my blackness whenever I get the chance to, so I've never hid in my whiteness. I've been accused of racial profiling and cultural appropriation though by no fault of my own.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I called myself a quadroon to my dad earlier today and he said a lot of black folk would kick my ass for saying that. I understand the historical disenfranchisement of black people and the continued cycle of poverty but I don\'t think all the cards are stacked against them as some make it seem. I can\'t really comment on experience since I am 100% white passing but I have my "black card" and can relate indirectly from my dad\'s experience.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: From what I've experienced, I tend to be far less PC than him. I don't think he's disgusted by it. He grew up with essentially only white people in his community so his parents taught him to be more cautious or aware of race. To answer your question, I look more like Taylor Swift, but Halsey is the closest example I could come up with. Halsey with blonde hair lol

WRITING.TITLE: b' '

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I\'m glad to hear that. My father has told me that people who are very particular about their identifiers have suggested that "mixed" falls into the same realm of incorrectness as "coloured" and the n-word. My boyfriend telling me about the mixed thing was the first time I\'d ever heard of it being offensive.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: He says that other POC with diverse ethnic origins have said that it\'s offensive. "Things are mixed, not humans," is the saying. He would call me biracial or just break down my genes instead of using a catch-all. I\'m not sure if it\'s because I\'m part black as opposed to another race. My dad (who is quite the character,) has referred to himself as mixed, mulatto, lightskin, and high y*llow.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Wow!! The shape and the length are amazing!!! I pay for my nails to look like this!!!

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Both are degree requirements. 214 is easy, but a lot of people struggled with 200. It's essentially a political philosophy course with a lot of reading.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Well I found that Y classes are much more rewarding than H classes because the time you devote to the class is longer. However, because of that, they seem a little tougher to me than H classes (but I doubt that this is a common phenomena- I get bored easily). I don't think it really matters much. 1 credit for the whole year vs 0.5 credit for half the year.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I had the same problem in second year. Just take 275 in third year.  I was freaking out about taking all the second year requirements in second year and I had multiple conflicts. I went to an academic advisor and they set me up all swell for second year. I think what is most important is to take the courses that are pre-requisites for upper year courses first instead of classes that you're particularly interested in. Get the boring stuff out of the way and then enjoy the rest of your years on the foundation that boring first and second year pre-reqs gave you.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Depends on your enrolment time and the course you're enrolling in. Courses that are degree requirements will fill up quicker than others.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I am both a polisci and philo major @ UTM. In my experience, philosophy has been the harder major just on the basis of the writing that is required. Both majors/minors will entail a lot of reading but the writing in philosophy is quite different compared to any other kind of academic writing. I quite enjoyed POL113 which is essentially an introduction to political philosophy. PHL101/102/103 (whichever) are good baseline philosophy courses. They don't go too in depth but the grading on writing can be quite harsh. A lot of POL classes are Y classes in upper years whereas in my experience PHL are mostly H. Good luck! If I were you, I would probably do POL113 and PHL103. Good luck! If you have questions I'd be happy to answer. :-)

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I'm curious about any possible contraindications with the products I'm currently using. I regularly introduce new products into my regimen (maybe once every three or four months, which I know has the potential to be problematic). I'm 19 and I really want to take care of my skin in the present and for the future. I struggle with occasional pimples (not acne per se,) large pores and scarring.  Usually I'm combination, but I have occasional bouts of dryness or excess oiliness. My skin is occasionally sensitive as well but not often. My regimen is the same for both day and night, apart from exfoliation as that is only done once or twice a week. I've been doing this for about a year. I don't wear makeup often, but when I do I prep and prime and always remove and cleanse. I live in Canada. I'm very open to changes or recommendations so please let me know! I'll do my best to answer questions too.  ***Cleansers***  Noxema Classic Clean or  Pixi Rose Cream cleanser or  Spectro Gel for Sensitive skin or  Holika Holika Aloe Facial Cleansing Foam *(particularly for makeup removal)*  Pixi Nourishing Cleansing Balm *(rarely used)*  ***Exfoliant***  St. Ives Radiant Skin Pink Lemon and and Mandarin Orange scrub *(used 1-2x weekly)*  Lavender Konjac sponge *(rotated in use with above)*  ***Toners***  Pixi Rose Tonic or  Burt's Bees Rosewater Toner or  Life brand Tea Tree oil toner or  ***Serums***  MD Selections Vitamin C Brightening Serum  Rosehip Oil by the Inkey List  NIP+FAB Dragons Blood Fix Serum  ***Moisturizers/Lotions***  Loreal Paris Nutri Gold day cream  Loreal Paris Hydra Genius Liquid Moisturizer For Normal and Dry Skin  Pixi Vitamin C Lotion  Neutrogena Oil-Free Moisture Broad Spectrum SPF 35  ***Spot Treatment***  Burt's Bees Herbal Complexion Stick *(used on problem spots)*  ***Facial Spray***  Pearlessence Rose and Coconut
